conclusion: Electron starts from rest and is accelerated by the electric field between the plate and cylinder 1.
Electric field inside the cylinders is zero, so the electron's acceleration is solely due to the electric field between the cylinders.
Electric field between two cylinders is given by E = U/d, where U is the potential difference between the cylinders and d is the distance between the cylinders.
Acceleration of the electron is a = U/d.
Time t for the electron to pass through the gap between cylinders is negligible, so the distance d can be considered constant.
Electron starts from rest and is accelerated by the electric field between the plate and cylinder 1.
Initial velocity v0 of the electron is 0.
Acceleration a is U/d.
Velocity v at the start of cylinder 1 is v0 + at, substituting v0 = 0, a = U/d, and t = 0, we get v = U/d.
Electron exits cylinder 1 along the central axis.
Velocity v at the exit of cylinder 1 is v.
Electron exits cylinder 2 along the central axis.
Velocity v at the exit of cylinder 2 is v.
Electron exits cylinder 3 along the central axis.
Velocity v at the exit of cylinder 3 is v.
Electron exits cylinder 4 along the central axis.
Velocity v at the exit of cylinder 4 is v.
Electron exits cylinder 5 along the central axis.
Velocity v at the exit of cylinder 5 is v.
Electron exits cylinder 6 along the central axis.
Velocity v at the exit of cylinder 6 is v.
Electron exits cylinder 7 along the central axis.
Velocity v at the exit of cylinder 7 is v.
Electron exits cylinder 8 along the central axis.
